III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Program statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents' needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth was observed to be dirty with bruises on his arm, which he
reported were caused by peers.
Investigation On 8/16/24 Complainant 1 reported Youth A left the facility on
8/15/24. Youth A was picked up by law enforcement at 11:45PM.
Youth A reported staff did not try to stop him from leaving the
facility. Youth A indicated he was being bullied at the facility and
had bruises on his left arm from other youth. Youth A was wearing
dirty clothing, had dirty feet, and smelled of feces. Attempts to
contact Complainant 1 occurred on 8/19/24 and 9/4/24. However,
no response was received.
Interviews:
Foster Care Worker was contacted by email on 8/16/24. Foster
Care Worker reported that Youth A went AWOL almost daily,
sometimes several times per day. Foster Care Worker reported
that Youth A showers at the facility, but he has previously had
accidents while AWOL. Youth A reported to Foster Care Worker
that peers bully him at times, but he has never indicated staff fail
to step in. Foster Care Worker stated that to her knowledge staff
break up any fights. Youth A is generally the instigator in
arguments. The facility notifies Foster Care Worker of any
concerns on a daily basis. Youth A does not listen well and
refuses to follow instructions and safety rules. This was an
ongoing issue prior to placement at this facility. Foster Care
Worker visits Youth A on a weekly basis and observed him to be
showered and dressed in clean clothing. Although it was noted he
refused to shower and change his clothes at times.
2

Follow-up occurred with Foster Care Worker on 9/25/24. They
continue to look at more secure placement options for Youth A.
Youth A continues to go AWOL frequently. Foster Care Worker
reported she was aware that staff would follow Youth A on foot for
a time, then contact the police, and drive around looking for youth.
It was clarified for Foster Care Worker that the facility did not have
a specific policy regarding one-to-one youth going AWOL.
Therefore, the facility would continue to follow their current policy.
Foster Care Worker stated she was aware and indicated the
facility has tried several techniques to keep Youth A from leaving.
Foster Care Worker planned to continue working with the facility to
address AWOL concerns until a new placement could be found.
On 8/19/24 Complainant 2 reported that Youth A made suicidal
statements and ran away from the facility due to bullying by peers.
Youth A was assigned a one-to-one staff. But when Youth A ran,
staff only followed for a short distance before calling the police.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 8/19/24.
Youth A showed some bruises on his upper left arm. The bruises
resembled two large letters, made of smaller bruises. Youth A
reported he did not know how he got the bruises, but believed
they were from “a couple days ago”. Youth A stated he though
staff grabbed his arm, but he was unsure of which staff, or what
day. Youth A showed several cuts and scratches on his hands,
elbows, and arms. Youth A was unsure how he obtained those but
did not indicate they were from staff or peers. Youth A stated he
did not go AWOL often. Youth A clarified that he went AWOL a
few times this week but did not go yesterday. Youth A stated
nothing happened while he was gone. Youth A stated that staff
tell him not to go AWOL, but he does anyway. Youth A then
walked out of the interview.
A follow-up interview was attempted on 9/4/24, but Youth A was
AWOL. Follow-up occurred on 9/12/24 at the facility. Youth A
reported he did not have any fights with peers. Youth A had
certain peers he did not get along with, but he was never physical
with them. Youth A stated that if fights occurred, staff would break
them up. Youth A denied any staff hurting him while at the facility.
Youth A then walked out of the interview.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 8/19/24.
Youth B stated he never saw any staff put their hands on, or harm,
any youth. Youth B never heard any staff threaten any youth.
Youth B stated that everyone is scheduled to shower every day, or
more often if needed.
3

Youth B denied seeing any peers or staff hurt Youth A. Youth B
stated that Youth A started fights with peers and spit at people.
Youth B never saw anyone pick on Youth A. Typically Youth A
was the one starting problems.
Youth B stated that when youth go AWOL, they lose privileges,
such as outings. Some youth, such as Youth A, AWOL all the time
and do not listen to staff. Staff would follow youth for a while in the
community, then contact the police for assistance.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 9/20/24.
Youth C was AWOL when an interview was initially attempted on
8/19/24. Youth C reported that staff always try to talk youth out of
going AWOL and will follow youth for a while through the
neighborhood. Youth C reported that staff stop following them on
foot after a while, due to safety concerns. Youth C reported the
safety concern was due to community members not liking staff.
When staff stop following on foot they will drive around and call
law enforcement to assist. Youth C stated that Youth A would go
AWOL a lot. Youth C was not aware of any peers bullying Youth
A. Youth A often started problems with peers by spitting on them
or getting physical with them. Youth A always had a one-to-one
staff that would intervene. Youth C stated that Youth A was never
alone with other youth, and he felt it was unlikely that anyone hurt
him while at the facility. Youth C had no knowledge of the bruises
on Youth A’s right arm. Youth C reported that everyone showers
every morning and sometimes again later in the day if needed.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 9/30/24.
Youth D stated that Youth A went AWOL a lot and did not listen to
staff. Youth A had one-to-one staff but would run from them. One-
to-one staff always stayed with youth until they ran from the facility
and got a few blocks away, then law enforcement was called. Staff
would also drive around and look for youth. Youth D never saw
anyone bully or attack Youth A. Youth D stated that everyone
showers every day at the facility.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 8/19/24.
Staff 1 reported Youth A struggled with his hygiene, but staff did
encourage him to shower every morning and again later in the day
if needed.
Staff 1 stated that Youth A often instigated situations with peers
and was physically aggressive with peers before. Staff 1 did not
witness any peers bullying Youth A. Youth A had one-to-one
4

staffing and staff were very aware of the signs Youth A showed
before a “blow up” occurred. Staff would attempt to remove Youth
A from situations, but he did not always listen. Staff would also
then remove the other youth from the area, but Youth A would
follow and continue to agitate the youth. Staff 1 stated that Youth
A can be hard to talk to and connect with at times.
Staff 1 was aware of the bruises on Youth A, but uncertain where
they came from. Staff 1 indicated the marks likely occurred while
Youth A was AWOL, as he left the facility frequently. Staff 1 stated
that staff discourage youth from leaving the property. However,
Youth A does not listen. Staff have tried to use incentives to
encourage him to stay, but he would leave anyway. Staff follow
youth to a designated perimeter then notify law enforcement for
assistance. There is not a specific policy for one-to-one staffed
youth.
Case Manager provided additional information on 8/30/24 via
email. Case Manager notified Foster Care Worker that additional
meetings were needed to discuss a more suitable placement for
Youth A. Youth A’s mother was very vocal with Youth A about her
plan to get the facility shut down, which has affected his behavior.
Youth A has been consistently violent toward staff and made
threats to have the facility closed. Youth A’s mother was asked to
refrain from making negative comments when speaking with
Youth A. However, she did not comply with this request. The
facility asked that DHHS supervise any future contact. Case
Manager reported that during a call on 8/30/24 Youth A told his
mother about an altercation with a peer. Case Manager saw the
altercation and felt the staff effectively managed the situation.
However, Youth A’s mother became irate and threatened to come
to the facility to confront the staff and youth involved. Youth A’s
mother stated that a different Wolverine program had been shut
down and she would see to it that this one was closed as well.
Case Manager interjected that the conversation was not
appropriate. However, Youth A’s mother continued to yell about
contacting MDHHS and closing the facility. Case Manager ended
the call and Youth A stated, “I’m getting this place shut down.”
Case Manager stated that staff work diligently to manage Youth
A’s behaviors daily. Youth A spits, kicks, and uses racial slurs at
staff and peers on a regular basis. Youth A defecated and
smeared feces at the facility. These behaviors increased as
contact has occurred with Youth A’s mother.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility. Staff 2 stated
that Youth A was frequently assaultive with peers and staff. Youth
5

A was not bullied to his knowledge. Youth A had a habit of being
the instigator, charging at people, spitting and calling names. Staff
2 was unsure how Youth A obtained the bruises on his arms but
believed it could have occurred while AWOL. Youth A went AWOL
several times over the past few weeks. Youth A never indicated
he was leaving because he was afraid of anyone. Staff 2 stated
that when youth would AWOL, staff follow for a while, then contact
law enforcement for assistance. This is the protocol as community
members have been threatening and violent toward staff, due to
youth yelling that staff are hurting them. There is not a specific
policy for youth that have one-to-one staffing.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility. Staff 3 stated
that all youth are encouraged to shower every morning and mor
often if needed. Youth A sometimes refuses to shower. But some
staff have better luck with him than others. Staff 3 reported that
Youth A instigates situations with peers by spitting and yelling
inappropriate things at them. Staff 3 was unaware of anyone
bullying Youth A. Staff 3 was unsure how Youth A received the
bruises on his arm. Staff 3 stated that when youth go AWOL, staff
try to talk to them and encourage them to come back. Staff would
then follow them and call law enforcement if needed.
Staff 4 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility. Staff 4 reported
that Youth A had several incidents of picking up sticks outside and
using them as weapons. Most youth tried to avoid Youth A, as he
was aggressive towards them. Staff 4 felt that Youth A was not
being bullied by any peers. However, peers were upset with Youth
A for his behavior at times. Staff 4 never witnessed any staff or
youth to be assaultive toward Youth A. Staff 4 reported that Youth
A always had one-to-one staff, so it would be unlikely that
something would happen without a witness. Staff 4 did not know
where the bruises on Youth A’s arm came from. Staff 4 stated that
youth shower every day. Although, some youth refuse, despite
staff encouragement. Staff 4 reported the agency procedure for
AWOL is to try to verbally redirect, then follow the youth until they
are past the identified boundary. Staff stop following after a certain
boundary due to community members being hostile toward staff.
When staff stop following by foot, law enforcement is called to
assist. Staff will also drive the neighborhood to look for youth at
times.
Staff 5 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 9/20/24.
Staff 5 denied seeing any youth bully or physically assault Youth
A. Staff 5 was unaware of the cause of any bruises on Youth A’s
arm. Staff 5 stated that Youth A went AWOL several times over
6

the past several months. When he returned, he was often very
dirty and would shower. Staff 5 stated that when youth AWOL,
staff follow on foot for a block, then contacted law enforcement.
Staff do not follow youth further because community members
have been threatening toward staff. Youth have told community
members that staff are hurting them, which has caused people to
yell, threaten and chase staff. Staff 5 verified there is not a specific
one-to-one policy regarding AWOL. One-to-one staff always
stayed with youth, until they leave facility grounds and were
deemed AWOL.
Staff 6 was interviewed by phone on 9/24/24. Staff 6 reported
she never saw anyone bully or hit Youth A. Staff 6 verified that
Youth A would go AWOL frequently, even with a one-to-one staff.
Staff would stay within arm’s reach of Youth A, until he left the
neighborhood. Then law enforcement would be called. Youth A
had a history of refusing to shower or change his clothes, despite
staff attempts to encourage him to maintain his hygiene. At times,
Youth A would return from AWOL with soiled clothing, due to
having an accident. Youth are given the opportunity to shower
twice per day.
Staff 7 was interviewed by phone on 9/24/24. Staff 7 stated he
worked with Youth A several times and never saw any youth
assault or bully him. Youth A often did things to irritate peers,
which caused them to avoid him. Youth A went AWOL frequently,
even though he had one-to-one staff, and staff would try to talk
with him and discourage him from leaving. Youth A did not listen
to staff well. Youth A was also not consistent with showering and
changing his clothes, even though there was a reward system in
place.
Staff 8 was interviewed by phone on 9/24/24. Staff 8 stated that
Youth A would AWOL frequently and staff would follow him until
they could no longer maintain line of sight. Youth A would often
return from AWOL very dirty, then shower. All youth are
encouraged to shower every morning. Staff 8 stated that Youth A
was not bullied by peers. Typically, Youth A was the one irritating
others and trying to get them to go after him. Youth A’s one-to-one
staff was always with him and would intervene if anything
happened and call for assistance if needed.
Staff 9 was interviewed by phone on 10/28/24. Staff 9 never
heard Youth A indicate he was going AWOL due to bullying. Staff
9 stated that Youth A would go AWOL often to smoke or look for
alcohol, not because of peer relationships. Staff 9 recalled that
7

Youth A was typically the one causing problems with peers and
staff would always intervene and remove youth from the situation.
When Youth A went AWOL staff would follow until they lost line of
sight, then contact law enforcement.
Staff 10 was interviewed by phone on 10/28/24. Staff 10 never
heard Youth A complain of being bullied. Staff 10 never saw Youth
A being bullied. Youth A was typically the instigator in problems
with peers. Youth A had a 1:1 and staff would separate youth
whenever there was an issue. When Youth A would go AWOL
staff would follow until he was out of sight then contact the police.
Staff 11 was interviewed by phone on 10/28/24. Staff 11 stated
that several peers were triggered by Youth A’s behaviors and
would react when he would do things to bother him. Youth A and
peers would argue back and forth. Staff would intervene and
break up any verbal situation before it became physical. Youth A
would go AWOL frequently. However, Staff 11 did not believe
bullying was the reason Youth A went AWOL. When Youth A
would leave the facility, staff would follow until they lost line of
sight. Staff would contact law enforcement after following the
youth for fifteen minutes, or when they lost line of sight.
Documents reviewed
• Foster Care record indicated Youth A was placed at the
facility from 6/19/24 to 10/11/24. Youth A went AWOL 69
times during that placement.
• Agency Policy regarding truancy does not address one-to-
one staffing. The policy states the following:
o Staff will make efforts to verbally redirect the
truanting client and offer support and alternatives to
truancy.
o Staff will immediately notify the supervisor on duty
when line of sight is lost, no later than 15 minutes
from loss of line of sight (when youth is determined
AWOL).
o Supervisor will ensure law enforcement is notified as
soon as youth is determined AWOL.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as staff and youth consistently
reported that Youth A was not bullied by peers and was given
daily opportunity to shower. Youth A reported no peers hurt
him. Youth A was unsure where the bruises and scratches came
from.
8

Regarding the agency’s AWOL practices, staff and youth
interviews indicate staff follow the process as outlined in agency
policy.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1)A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention: (a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not
limited to: (ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or
pushing a youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A was pinched during a restraint.
Investigation On 8/19/24 Complainant 2 reported that Youth A was restrained
at the facility on 8/17/24. During the restraint, Youth A was
pinched.
Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 8/19/24.
Youth A was asked about a restraint that occurred on 8/17/24.
Youth A stated he was outside at the time but could not remember
what he was doing. Youth A could not recall anything about the
restraint and did not remember which staff were involved. Youth A
stated he was not hurt in the restraint. Youth A then walked out of
the interview.
A follow-up interview was attempted on 9/4/24, but Youth A was
AWOL. Follow-up occurred on 9/12/24 at the facility. Youth A
denied any staff hurting him while at the facility. Youth A then
walked out of the interview.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 8/19/24.
Youth B stated he never saw any staff harm any youth. Youth B
recalled seeing Youth A restrained one time, although he could
not recall the date. Staff held Youth A’s arms and legs until he
calmed down. Youth B did not see staff do anything inappropriate.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 9/20/24.
Youth C was AWOL when an interview was initially attempted on
9

8/19/24. Youth C had no knowledge of the bruises on Youth A’s
right arm. Youth C denied seeing staff pinch or injure Youth A.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 9/30/24.
Youth D denied seeing any staff pinch or injure Youth A.
Staff 8 was interviewed by phone on 9/24/24. Staff 8 did not recall
any restraints where Youth A received an injury. Staff 8 denied
ever pinching Youth A or observing any staff pinch him.
Staff 9 was interviewed by phone on 10/28/24. Staff 9 reported
that he was involved in a few restraints with Youth A throughout
his time there. Staff 9 did not specifically recall the restraint on
8/17/24. However, he did not remember hearing Youth A ever
complain of being pinched in a restraint. Staff 9 never witnessed
any staff pinch or injure Youth A in a restraint.
Staff 10 was interviewed by phone on 10/28/24. Staff 10 recalled
being involved in restraints with Youth A. However, he did not
recall the restraint on 8/17/24. Staff 10 denied ever hearing Youth
A complain of being pinched in a restraint. Staff 10 denied
observing any staff pinch or injure Youth A in a restraint.
Staff 11 was interviewed by phone on 10/28/24. Staff 11 recalled
the restraint on 8/17/24. Staff 11 denied pinching, or seeing any
other staff pinch, Youth A. Staff 11 stated the restraint was very
well supervised and done correctly. Staff 11 stated that she
remembered Youth A yelling at staff to let him go. Youth A would
yell false allegations at times to make staff back away.
Documents reviewed
• Incident reports for 8/17/24 were reviewed. Youth A was
restrained at 5:25 and 5:58PM due to aggressive and
violent behavior. Youth A kicked and spit at staff, punched
staff in the face, hit staff with a stick, attempted to throw his
feces at staff, and ran in front of cars. Staff attempted to
avoid restraint by giving Youth A space, talking with him,
changing staff, and blocking his hits. In the first restraint,
Youth A was placed in a high seated hold briefly but
released as he bit a staff. In the second restraint, Youth A
was placed in a supine restraint, where staff were able to
successfully verbally deescalate him. Youth A initially
refused to go to the hospital for an assessment, but later
agreed and went to St. John Hospital. Staff 8, 9, 10 and 11
were involved/present for this restraint.
10

Analysis The agency is found in compliance as there was insufficient
information to support the allegation.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules.
